Portal es un juego de puzzles que a simple vista es sencillo, pero cuenta con un gameplay muy creativo e innovador, puede que la historia sea secundaria pero el juego sabe como dejarte siempre con ganas del siguiente nivel o desafio. Introduce un personaje muy memorable, [spoiler]GLaDOS[/spoiler] y la pistola de portales, lo mas reconocible del t√≠tulo. Es un juego de corta duraci√≥n pero de alta calidad.

[h1][8.7/10][h1]
The cake wasn't a lie and I missed it ;(

With modern gaming flooded by first person shooting games and fantasy games, Portal is a game with an original concept, a unique setting, challenging gameplay, and one of the most memorable video game villian of all time. Buy cake for a reward after you finish it.  



9/10

I love this game, almost as much as the second one.  This is one game I'd consider legendary as it also has a pretty large cult following too.  I'm also quite the fan of killer AI scenarios so it gets extra points for that too.

Gran cl√°sico atemporal en los juegos de puzles con una trama algo simple pero muy bien llevada.
Todo un referente que ha marcado un antes y un despu√©s en el g√©nero de los puzles de plataformas.
Se hace corto pero es muy intenso y divertido por la manera en la que te hace pensar.

PROS:
- Una trama simple pero efectiva bastante bien guionizada.
- Puzles con una buena curva de dificultad.
- Sistema de juego innovador.

CONTRAS:
- Dificultad algo baja en t√©rminos generales.
- Mec√°nicas algo repetitivas.
- Muy corta duraci√≥n (3-4 horas)

El juego te volar√° la cabeza, puesto que a pesar de no ser muy largo debes pensar en que hacer para poder avanzar, los puzzles son complejos y te hacen sentir atrapado de verdad, no podr√°s dejar de jugar y quedaras enviciado hasta lograr descubrir como avanzar al siguiente nivel.

Really good puzzle game, I love GLaDOS' sarcasm.

You wake up inside a small, glass cubicle.

In one corner of the cubicle is a small white coffee table. On the table there is a clipboard, an empty mug and a radio which repeats the same upbeat, voiceless tune over and over. Attached to the clipboard is an information sheet with square, yellow symbols which appear to depict a person being subjected to a variety of weird hazards. The last symbol is of a slice of cake.

In the second corner of the room there is a toilet.

The final object in the room is the most siginificant: it's the stasis pod from which you just woke up. It's glass dome lid has slid back into place.

Having taken in the cubicle and all it's contents, you realise there is no way out.

Beyond the glass of the cubicle there is a corridor which surrounds it. Through the glass you can see a timer attached to the wall, counting down from one minute. Below the timer are two vertical, parallel neon blue lines which seem to have been embossed into the wall. On the other side of the cubicle, through the glass and just above you there is a window of frosted glass. Through the diffusion you can make out a door, monitors, desks... it looks like an observation room, but it has no observers. To the left of this observation window is what looks like a security camera with a small dot of red light in the centre of the lens.

Suddenly you hear an electronic blip and then a voice speaks, "Hello and again welcome to the Apeture Science Computer-Aided Enrichment Center." The voice is robotic, artificial but unmistakeably female.

"We hope your brief detention in the relaxation vault has been a pleasant one. Your specimen has been processed and we are now ready to begin the test proper. Before we start, however, keep in mind that although fun and learning are the primary goals of the enrichment center activities, serious injuries may occur. For your own safety, and the safety of others, please refrain from..." there is a static noise and then the voice suddenly speeds up and becomes so fast it's unintelligible. This only lasts for a few seconds.

"......dfdoprjdrgaback. The portal will open in three... two... one..."

**************************

There you have it, the opening scene of Portal. I wanted to write that because of how significant it is that this game doesn't give you any background information or introductory cutscene. Instead it's just like, "Start New Game. Wake up. Play." This is not the first time Valve Software has pulled this trick (see Half-Life: "You're Gordon Freeman. You're on a tram. Play."), but it's as effective as ever because the onus is on you, the player, to discover what the hell is going on!

Now if you've never played Portal, I'm not going to divulge any further details. As stated above, filling in the blanks is exactly what the creators of the game intented you to do. That's YOU, not me, or any other reviewer or player or magazine or YouTuber. Just you. If you're intrigued, buy this game right now if you can and you'll never regret it.

If you have played Portal, I'm still not saying anything for two reasons: one, the person reading this who hasn't played is probably still reading (why are you still reading? Go play this game right now!) Two: there are plenty of reviews and retrospectives on this game already out there which I cannot improve upon or contribute to. Suffice to say, while I don't feel the game is beyond critisism it is still a must-play game simply because it creates one of the greatest gameplay mechanics of all time and runs with it. It's unique, addictive, mysterious, engaging and there's nothing else like it.
The best game you can get for under $5
One of the best protal games I've played.

[b]+[/b] For any person exploring through challenges to solve, [i]Portal[/i] is the perfect choice. The gameplay is simple, but the puzzles are complex, and it is all about being physical. Portals to fire and, cubes, buttons, physical education, turrets, and more all add to the numerous possibilities of unique puzzles.
[b]+[/b] Have you ever played a game besides this where the player is armed with a portal gun and can shoot portals most of everywhere and walk, jump, fall, or fly into them to get to most other places? My guess is no, unless the game was a [i]Portal[/i] clone, and it shows Valve's creativity at their finest.
[b]+[/b] The story and character development are also well-done. The story is riddled not with clich√©s, but with tongue-in-cheek and ironic dialogue. Chell, the player character, may be silent, but she is intelligent and perhaps the superhero in science, and GlaDOS, the ever-sarcastic mega-robot in control of the entire Aperature facility, shows potential in becoming an excellent supervillain.
[b]+[/b] In case the story is perceived to be short, Bonus Maps offers Advanced Chambers, which are some 6 levels from campaign but each structurally modified to toughen their difficulty, and Challenge Maps, which are composed of the same 6 levels in their unmodified form that can be played against either of the requirements: the number of portals created, the number of footsteps taken, or the amount of time to complete the chamber. Is there more than one solution in thoroughly finishing a level? I will let you find out.
[b]-[/b] Very short campaign with little or underdeveloped plot that could be completed on an average of about 4 hours. (To Valve's credit, though, the budget to make what might never have gone on to become such a commercial success was relatively low, and the introductory price to purchase this game was also low, so there is that.)

[b]SCORE: 90%[/b]

PROs
One of my all time favorite games. No clue why I didn't review it back in the day. I have run through it multiple times and even played the Developer Commentary version. The puzzles are a delight and the backstory is intriguing.

CON
The only downside to the game is the meme nonsense, but perhaps that is to be expected considering how amazing this game is.

In short, it is a Tier3 game, or my name is not cjohnson. I dedicate this review to Doug R.
